solution_04_inferential_statistics/01_T_dist/01_T_probs_v2

video

app

You can use a \(t\) table. Remember, the degree of freedom (df or \(\nu\)) is one less than \(n\). \[\text{df} = n-1 \]

Spreadsheet

You can use T.DIST and T.INV to calculate the values. But remember these functions return/use LEFT-area probabilities.

R

You can use pt and qt to calculate the values. But remember these functions return/use LEFT-area probabilities.


  1. When \(n=12\), then \(\text{df}=11\) and \(P(T<2.72)=0.99\).
  2. When \(n=2\), then \(\text{df}=1\) and \(P(T>63.66)=0.005\).
  3. When \(n=4\), then \(\text{df}=3\) and \(P(|T|<5.84)=0.99\).
  4. When \(n=17\), then \(\text{df}=16\) and \(P(|T|>1.34)=0.2\).
  5. When \(n=33\), then \(\text{df}=32\) and \(P(T<2.45)=0.99\), so \(t=2.45\).
  6. When \(n=9\), then \(\text{df}=8\) and \(P(T>1.4)=0.1\), so \(t=1.4\).
  7. When \(n=40\), then \(\text{df}=39\) and \(P(|T|<2.12)=0.96\), so \(t=2.12\).
  8. When \(n=34\), then \(\text{df}=33\) and \(P(|T|>2.44)=0.02\), so \(t=2.44\).
